speaker: Dan
text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Dan, and joining me today is Neil. Hi Neil.

speaker: Neil
text: Hi, everyone!

speaker: Dan
text: Bless you! Are you ok?

speaker: Neil
text: I think I’m coming down with something serious.

speaker: the sniffles
text: It’s just a case of the sniffles.

speaker: Thesnifflesa runny nose
text: The sniffles is an informal way of saying a cold or flu. It comes from the sniffing sound people make when they have a runny nose.

speaker: runny nosesoldier on
text: And a runny nose is when liquid mucus keeps leaking from our nose – usually when we are sick. I’m afraid you’ll just have to soldier on Neil.

speaker: To soldier on
text: To soldier on means to continue despite difficulty. I’m dying! What’s it about anyway?

speaker: Dan
text: It’s about ‘man flu’, and whether it’s actually real, or just something men like to complain about. We'll give you 6 words and expressions – and, of course, our quiz question.

speaker: Neil
text: Alright, fire away.

speaker: Dan
text: In a survey conducted by Nuts magazine that asked its readers how long they took to recover from a cold or flu, where women put an average of 1.5 days, what did men put?

speaker: Dan
text: a) 1 day

speaker: Dan
text: b) 2 days

speaker: Dan
text: c) 3 days

speaker: Neil
text: I’m going to say 3 days. The threat of ‘man flu’ is real.

speaker: Man flu
text: Well, we’ll find out later, but let’s clarify. ‘Man flu’ is the tendency that many people believe men have to complain about a minor illness, such as a cold or flu, and act as if they were suffering from something a lot more serious.

speaker: Neil
text: Yes. But science cannot say whether men do actually suffer more than women, or if men just tend to complain more.

speaker: Dan
text: Well, let’s hear from this British couple about whether they think ‘man flu’ is real or not.

speaker: British Man
text: Men definitely do suffer a lot more, I think, than women do when we get flu.

speaker: British Woman
text: Yeah, I’m not so convinced. I feel like they just complain more.

speaker: British Man
text: It wipes me out.

speaker: British Man
text: British Woman

speaker: British Man
text: I was ill recently and I just carried on and went to work and everything. And when Chris had got sick recently he was on the sofa and couldn’t really do anything, so…

speaker: Dan
text: And it seems that it’s not just in the UK. Listen to this BBC Journalist interviewing a woman from Europe.

speaker: BBC Journalist
text: You’re from the Netherlands. Have you ever accused your boyfriend of having man flu?

speaker: Dutch woman
text: Oh, absolutely yes. Yeah.

speaker: BBC Journalist
text: What have you accused him of doing?

speaker: whining
text: …whining?

speaker: Whining
text: Whining is when someone complains repeatedly and often in an annoying way about something. So, there certainly seems to be something there…but nothing has been proven, right?

speaker: Dan
text: Well, a recent scientific study has indicated that there could be something to ‘man flu’ after all. Doctor Kyle Sue, an assistant professor of family medicine at Memorial University of Newfoundland in Canada, has suggested that there could be a difference between men and women when it comes to respiratory diseases.

speaker: symptoms
text: Respiratory meaning related to breathing. He says that there was already a lot of evidence from existing studies suggesting men experience worse, longer-lasting symptoms.

speaker: Symptoms
text: Symptoms are the feelings of illness caused by a disease. Listen to him explain why this is.

speaker: Doctor Kyle Sue
text: Doctor Kyle Sue,

speaker: Memorial University, Newfoundland
text: It seems that the higher the testosterone levels, the lower the immune response to these types of infections, whereas the higher the oestrogen level, the stronger the immune response.

speaker: Neil
text: Testosterone and oestrogen are hormones that exist in both men and women. Testosterone is higher in males and oestrogen is higher in females. Dr. Sue’s research suggests that the more oestrogen a person has, the better able they are to fight off the infection. That’s it then! Man flu is real!

speaker: Dan
text: Hold your horses, Neil. There are two problems. First of all, the Royal college of GPs in the UK says that there is no such thing as ‘man flu’. And secondly, even Dr Sue admits that these results, including his own, are only ‘suggestive’ and are not ‘definitive’.

speaker: Neil
text: So, basically he’s saying that there is a suggestion that ‘man flu’ exists, but the evidence so far cannot say for sure.

speaker: Dan
text: Exactly. More studies need to be done. But you know what we can be sure about? The answer to this week’s quiz question. I asked you in a survey conducted by Nuts magazine that asked its readers how long they took to recover from a cold or flu, where women put an average of 1.5 days, what did men put?

speaker: Dan
text: a) 1 day

speaker: Dan
text: b) 2 days

speaker: Dan
text: c) 3 days

speaker: Neil
text: And I said 3 days.

speaker: Dan
text: And you were right!

speaker: Neil
text: Good!

speaker: Dan
text: The men said they took twice as long to recover!

speaker: Neil
text: It must be all that manly testosterone. Let’s review our vocabulary, shall we?

speaker: the snifflesthe sniffles
text: Our first was the sniffles. If you have the sniffles, you have a cold, informally speaking. What's the best cure for the sniffles Neil?

speaker: runny nose
text: Stay in bed and sweat it out, my mum always said. Just make sure you have lots of tissues to deal with your runny nose. That’s when a person’s nose leaks mucus, usually because they are ill. Yuck!

speaker: soldier onsoldier on
text: Next we had soldier on. This phrasal verb means to continue despite difficulty. When was the last time you had to soldier on, Neil?

speaker: man flu
text: A few days ago when I went the whole day without eating any lunch! Then we had ‘man flu’. That’s is the name given to the situation where a person, often a man, tends to complain and exaggerate a small illness such as a cold. Do you do that, Dan?

speaker: whiningwhine
text: I’m sure my wife would say I do! Next we had whining. If you whine, you complain repeatedly and often in an annoying way.

speaker: symptoms
text: Like my children did last time I didn’t buy them ice-cream. And finally we had symptoms. These are the feelings of illness caused by a disease. What are the symptoms of flu, Dan?

speaker: Dan
text: A headache, aching muscles, and a fever. And that’s the end of this 6 Minute English! Don’t forget to check out our YouTube, Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pages. There you made it. You can collapse now.
